data.text: Contents
Introduction
Water of the appropriate quality used in the preparation of dialysis fluid is an essential requirement of haemodialysis and related therapies.

Quality requirements for the water used to prepare dialysis fluid are provided in a series of standards issues by the British Standards Institute. The rationale for the development of these standards is to protect haemodialysis patients from adverse effects arising from known chemical and microbiological contaminants found in water.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to detail the roles and responsibilities, protocols to support service delivery and the action to be taken if tests results do not meet the required standards.
Definitions

table_items.text: Fluid made from dialysis water and concentrates that is delivered to the dialyser by the dialysis fluid delivery system. Synonyms such as “dialysate” or “dialysis solution” may be used in place of dialysis fluid.

Water that has been treated to meet the specified limits for chemical and microbial contaminants in BS ISO 13959;2015 and is suitable for use in haemodialysis applications, which include the preparation of dialysis fluid, reprocessing of dialysers, preparation of concentrates and preparation of substitution fluid for online convective therapies.

Water supplied to a water treatment system or an individual component of a water treatment system. Synonyms such as raw water, source water, supply water or potable water may be used instead of feed water.

Water produced by a water treatment system or an individual component of a water treatment system. Synonyms such as permeate, treated water, purified water or reverse osmosis water may be used instead of product water. However this does not specify any limits, and consequently the International Standards introduce the term dialysis water.
Potent pyrogenic materials arising from the outer layers of

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Estates Facilities Management (EFM) Water Hygiene Committee duties are:
4.1.1 To receive and review water quality of the dialysis water
4.1.2 To receive reports from the responsible person Maintenance Services
4.1.3 To receive reports from the responsible person Medical Equipment Management Services
4.1.4 To receive chemical analysis reports from the lead Renal Nurse
4.1.5 To review and agree any key actions with the lead Renal Consultant
4.1.6 To agree an investment strategy for present and future requirements in order to facilitate the effective control of renal dialysis water systems

4.1.7 To receive management reports from the multidisciplinary team (MEMS / Renal staff / Maintenance Staff / Contractors) so that the group can review performance against agreed standards and escalate variations via subcommittees to the Board
4.1.8 To monitor the actions taken in line with the findings of failed water quality tests samples
Infection Prevention Control Committee
4.2.1  Receive assurance on the quality of dialysis water reporting key variations to the Quality Assurance Committee, who in turn reports to the Trust Board.
MSE Kidney Governance Group

4.3.1  To ensure a comprehensive reporting system and communication with all members of the various services is maintained, to monitor the effectiveness of the arrangements via the water hygiene committee and ultimately to the Trust Board via the above governance structure.
Chief Executive Officer (CEO)

4.4.1  The Chief Executive Officer has the overall responsibility for health and safety within MSE FT, and has the ultimate responsibility for the implementation of this policy and operational arrangements for the control of water systems.
Director of Estates and Facilities

4.5.1  The Board of Directors and the Chief Executive Officer have agreed that responsibility for controlling and co-ordinating EFM and, therefore, the control of water systems is delegated to the Director of Estates and Facilities. The Director of Estates and Facilities will ensure that operational arrangements and systems are in place, monitored and reviewed and that appropriate resources are available.
Haemodialysis service lead
4.6.1 The senior clinician in charge of the renal unit (or designated deputy) has responsibility for the overall clinical governance of the water treatment facility.

4.6.2 This safeguard also highlights that the ultimate responsibility for clinical governance for the renal unit should rest with the clinical director of the renal unit or a designated deputy, since they are responsible for the clinical care of the patient.
Renal Nurses responsibilities

4.7.1 The clinician in charge of the renal unit may appoint a deputy, who may be a senior renal technology specialist or a consultant renal specialist, to take responsibility for the water treatment facility and act as line manager for clinical governance.
4.7.2 The Renal Nursing staff will ensure monitoring for chemical contaminants follows agreed procedures and is reported to the Lead Clinician and Water Hygiene committee.
Medical Equipment Management Services (MEMS)

4.8.1 Responsibility to ensure an effective management system is in place for the systematic approach to the acquisition; deployment; maintenance (preventive maintenance and performance assurance), repair and disposal of the Haemodialysis equipment, compliant with MHRA guidance.
4.8.2 Specialist medical equipment support is provided by the In-house MEMS team and external contractors in accordance with manufacturers recommendations.
4.8.3 Guidance including CAS alerts, manufacturer safety notices and legislation affecting the management of haemodialysis equipment is actioned and reported.
4.8.4 Equipment maintenance schedules and maintenance reports are recorded on the Medusa equipment management system.
4.8.5 Performance is monitored via Key Performance Indicators (KPI's), KPI's are reviewed and monitored through the MEMS quality management system.
4.8.6 Monthly and quarterly monitoring reports are provided to the EFM Board and CAC respectively.
Specialist Maintenance Equipment Contractor – Haemodialysis equipment

4.9.1  These contractors are appointed by MEMS to provide specialist planned and reactive maintenance, they repair services to the Haemodialysis treatment machines in accordance with the agreed SLA. They should provide the Trust with maintenance and repair reports.
The MEMS Medical Equipment Training Co-ordinator
4.10.1 Assist managers and users, to identify Haemodialysis equipment training needs
4.10.2 Identify training requirements with new equipment
4.10.3 Facilitate training delivery by an appointed training officer
Head of Engineering
4.11.1  The post holder will ensure:

Documentation is in place to demonstrate that the Renal Dialysis water sampling schedule and associated outcomes meets the required monitoring for microbiological contaminants and provide information based on trend analysis.

Operating procedures are in place which details the procedures to be followed by internal maintenance staff and external contractors; this should include actions / reporting processes to be taken if the prescribed limits are exceeded.

Maintenance operators and external contractors are trained in the use / monitoring of the water treatment facility. The training should be specific to the functions performed. Competence with procedures should be assessed and documented. Periodic audits of the operators' compliance with procedures should be undertaken and documented and there should be an on-going training programme to maintain the operator's knowledge and skills.
Specialist Water Services Contractor
4.12.1 Technical contracts provided to specialist contracts should follow recommended guidance on water testing
4.12.2 The test procedures used for monitoring microbial contamination of water for dialysis should be appropriate to the type of organisms found in water and need to be adhered to stringently.
4.12.3 Contractors must support the renal services to identify specific plans of action if results are outside of the required parameters.
Specialist Maintenance Equipment Contractor- Water treatment plant

4.13.1  Needs to ensure clear instructions are in place to support the Trusts staff. Ensure reactive maintenance and testing reports with associated action plans are provided. Provide formal feedback to the Water Hygiene Committee.
Water Treatment Facility

The water treatment facility is designed to produce dialysis quality water from feed water. The facility is housed in a dedicated, secured and access controlled water or “plant” room and fitted to provide source water, drains and electric power. The plant room should be well organised, uncluttered, clean and dry. There should be no water leaks or unpleasant odours. There should be up-to-date signage and flow diagrams indicating the direction of water movement and on and off valve positions, along with a log book listing system components with recording device pressures, water flow readings and purity measures by the facility team. Each system component should be labelled and component manufacturers should be identified on each label, including contact information and a source for the manufacturer's recommendations on correct use.

There should be clear lines of communication established between the nephrologists and internal or external staff responsible for the operation and maintenance of the equipment. Good record keeping in association with robust lines of communication should be established between senior renal unit personnel and those who undertake the monitoring and maintenance of the water equipment plant to ensure that there is a timely transfer of information.

The maintenance and monitoring of the water treatment facilities for haemodialysis should be performed by the equivalent of an NHS renal technologist who has a full understanding of theory/ maintenance of water treatment for haemodialysis.
Figure showing picture of water facility and schematic diagram of the components.
Quality Control
An external Specialist Contractor is responsible for water testing and reporting of results, to review the results and act accordingly until the results have returned to safe levels.
Frequency of monitoring of chemical contaminants

The  concentrations  of  chemical  contaminants  in  water  used  to  prepare dialysis fluid should be monitored at least 3 monthly, apart from chlorine which should be monitored at least weekly. Chemical contaminants should not exceed the limits stated in table 1:
Table 1: Chemical Contaminants

6.2.1 Considerable daily as well as seasonal variations in the chlorine and chloramine levels of the feed water are known to exist and therefore the guidance to test for total chlorine at least weekly should be regarded as an absolute minimum. If practical and feasible, testing for chlorine or chloramine on a daily or shift basis is recommended. It is however recognised that such an approach may place an undue burden on staff, and if it can be demonstrated that the chlorine levels in the feed water are consistently low (<0.5 mg/L) and chloramines are not used, then weekly monitoring of the dialysis water is sufficient. However, if chloramines are used and the level of total chlorine in the feed water exceeds 1.0 mg/L, daily or shift based monitoring should be adopted.

6.2.2 It is normal practice to measure the total chlorine of the product water after the carbon filters as reverse osmosis membranes are susceptible to oxidative damage by free chlorine. The maximum exposure to chlorine of the reverse osmosis membrane should be ascertained from the system supplier.
6.2.3 A programme of improvement should begin immediately if routine monitoring demonstrates that concentrations of chemical contaminants exceed the maximum allowable limits.

6.2.4 Testing for chemical contaminants will normally include continuous conductivity monitoring of the water leaving the reverse osmosis system, and regular in-house checks of hardness and total chlorine.
Frequency of monitoring of microbial contaminants and endotoxin

6.3.1  The concentration of microbiological contaminants (total viable counts and endotoxin) in water used for preparation of the dialysis fluid should be monitored at least monthly and not exceed recommended limits (100CFU/ML for bacteria and

0.25 EU/ml for endotoxin). If routine monitoring demonstrates microbiological contaminant levels in excess of 50 CFU/ml and 0.125 EU/ml for bacteria and endotoxin (50% of the maximum permitted levels) a programme of corrective measures should be commenced immediately. Concentrations of chemical contaminants in product water used to prepare dialysis fluid shall not exceed the limits stated in BS EN ISO 13959:2015: water for haemodialysis and related therapies. A programme of improvements should begin immediately if routine monitoring demonstrates that concentrations of chemical contaminants exceed the maximum allowable limits.
Training Requirements
Operation of the water pre-treatment systems

7.1.1 The operation of the water treatment facility should only be carried out by persons who have been trained and accredited by the manufacturer or their UK distributor. Records of who is responsible for the operation of all or part of the water treatment facility should be maintained within the dialysis unit. Competence with procedures should be assessed and documented. Periodic audits of the operators' compliance with procedures should be undertaken and documented and there should be an ongoing training programme to maintain the operator's knowledge and skills.
Obtaining suitable water samples

7.2.1 Testing of water samples should be carried out by trained and accredited persons or laboratories and records maintained within the dialysis unit, managed by external Specialist Contractor and records kept in the dialysis facilities.
7.2.2 Operating procedures for water sample testing should be obtained from the Specialist Contractor to include:
Information on how to collect the water sample,
where the sample is collected from, and
what the water sample is collected in and
how the sample is maintained up to the time it is tested
7.2.3 The reporting process and the responsible person should be clearly identified in the operating procedure.
Monitoring and Audit

Monitoring and reporting on contaminant should be via the water Hygiene, Renal management committee, the former in turn reports to the infection control committee and quality assurance committee, and then the Trust board.
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Duties relating to the repair and maintenance of dialysis equipment
Monitoring of dialysis water and dialysis fluid quality

data.text: Routine testing procedures for water for dialysis should have standard operating procedures in place for sapling, monitoring of the feed and product water quality.
Contingency plans should describe how to deal with events that prevent dialysis being performed. Please see business continuity plan for details.
Recording and trending results

8.5.1 All water test results should be recorded and trended over time by the facilities/maintenance department. Trending may be done on a graph (e.g. with the results being obtained by averaging the last ten test results). The trending result will show if there is any slight changes of test results over time. Test results and

trending graphs should be maintained in a Quality folder which is kept in the Estates Department. Trends are reported biannually to the Renal Department at the renal management meeting at the end of the 2nd and 4th quarter as part of the Quality process for both areas.

8.5.2 The trended water test results should be reviewed at the Water Assurance Committee. Quarterly reviewing of results should show any trend that may require intervention to prevent contaminated product reaching the haemodialysis equipment of patients. Individual sites review water results and liaise with the external Specialist Contractor when deviations occur to ensure action is taken and results return to acceptable limits.
Action when abnormal test results are obtained

8.6.1  It is essential that any elevated results are promptly communicated to responsible senior staff. The external Specialist Contractor is responsible for retesting abnormal results and communicating changes until results return to acceptable levels.
Home haemodialysis monitoring of water

8.7.1 Monitoring records should be provided by the renal unit and used to record all measure of the water treatment system performance. Measurements should be taken at least 15 minutes after the water treatment system has been set in operation and before dialysis is initiated. To ensure that dialysis is undertaken with suboptimal water quality, prior to each treatment.

8.7.2 If the reverse osmosis system is sound to be outside its acceptable range, the renal unit responsible for the patient should be notified. If the water treatment includes a standalone softener, the water hardness should be monitored prior to each treatment. For hardness tests requiring colour differentiation, the person performing the analysis should be able to distinguish between the colours of blue, purple and red. If the person cannot differentiate between these colours an automated meter should be used. The results should be recorded on the log sheet and reviewed by the renal technologist as part of the maintenance and service of the home haemodialysis installation.
Monitoring for chemical and microbiological quality

8.8.1 The chemical quality of the product water used for dialysis should be analysed at least every 6 months to ensure it meets the required standard. If there are seasonal variations in the source water quality or it is fed from a well more frequent testing may be indicated. When any repairs or component replacements are made to water treatment equipment, the impact on water quality should be evaluated and a chemical analysis performed if indicated. A log sheet should be provided be the Renal unit and used to record water performance. If the reverse osmosis plant is found to be outside the acceptable range, the renal unit should notify the patient. The chemical quality of the dialysis water should be analysed every 6 months. If the is a longer period of time between testing, documentation should be in place with detail about rationale.

8.8.2 A log sheet should be provided be the Renal unit and used to record water performance. If the reverse osmosis plant is found to be outside the acceptable range, the renal unit should notify the patient. The chemical quality of the dialysis water should be analysed every 6 months. If the is a longer period of time between testing, documentation should be in place with detail about rationale.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Clinical Governance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local MSE Kidney Clinical Governance Group. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Kidney Clinical Governance Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)

data.text: Resampling
Whenever it is necessary to resample because of failed water quality tests, the Responsible person will contact all relevant personnel

table_items.text: No specific action required Responsible Person to e mail relevant personnel

Responsible Person to e mail relevant personnel Check trend in previous results Renal Consultant to make decision safe to dialyse patients If trend increasing, resample If resample high, then sanitise RO unit Renal Consultant to make decision safe to dialyse patients

Responsible Person to e mail relevant personnel Renal Consultant to make decision safe to dialyse patients Resample Renal Consultant to make decision safe to dialyse patients If bicarbonate concentrate or dialysis fluid <100, no immediate action required If bicarbonate concentrate or dialysis fluid high, then sanitisation of RO unit required If resample of RO>100, sanitise unit and document corrective action
